content.raw: It was for debugging. I've created issue #447 to track this.
content.html: It was for debugging. I've created issue #447 to track this.

content.raw: The bullet function is a pass by reference, so we have to dereference the pointer to the bullet rigid body. I added some parentheses to clarify the dereference.
content.html: The bullet function is a pass by reference, so we have to dereference the pointer to the bullet rigid body. I added some parentheses to clarify the dereference.

content.raw: This was an incorrect conditional that would throw unless a joint had both child and parent links specified. If one of the links is the world, then it will not have a link pointer. This is replaced with a check at line 116.
content.html: This was an incorrect conditional that would throw unless a joint had both child and parent links specified. If one of the links is the world, then it will not have a link pointer. This is replaced with a check at line 116.

content.raw: I fixed this for all of the bullet constraints.
content.html: I fixed this for all of the bullet constraints.

update.description:
The main feature of this pull request is a fix for bullet's revolute joint (BulletHingeJoint) so that it passes the same pendulum test as ODE (SimplePendulumTest). I did have to tweak the inertial parameters slightly in simple_pendulums_bullet.world, changing inertia values from 0 to 1e-6, so it does differ insubstantially from the ODE test.

I also made a few static functions in BulletTypes for converting between gazebo and bullet Vector3 and poses.

I filled in the BulletLink::OnPoseChange, so that Reset Model Poses, Reset World, and the move/rotate tools work.

I fixed a bug in the processing of physics messages, so the update rate, step size, and gravity can be adjusted from the gui.

I also added Link::GetWorldCoGPose, which is useful since the bullet functions define everything relative to the center of gravity of a rigid body.

I also added a SpawnDropCoG test, which spawns several spheres of different radii and different center of gravity locations. It's currently failing; I believe it is related to physics engine parameters, which will be addressed in a future pull request. I've added the failing tests to the description of issue #349.
update.title: Bullet integration: simple pendulum

content.html: Comment for this, and the line above.

content.html: Add a comment about the following math.

content.html: Why do you have to dereference the shared pointer?

content.raw: Can you put curly brackets for the `if` blocks. I know it doesn't need them, but the code is more readable is multi-line if blocks are wrapped in brackets.
content.html: Can you put curly brackets for the if blocks. I know it doesn't need them, but the code is more readable is multi-line if blocks are wrapped in brackets.

this->btHinge2

Also, don't use the `bt` prefix. It might be better to use `bulletHinge2`.
content.html:
this->btHinge2

Also, don't use the bt prefix. It might be better to use bulletHinge2.

content.raw: Can you reword this to be "Get the pose of the body's center of gravity in the world coordinate frame"?
content.html: Can you reword this to be "Get the pose of the body's center of gravity in the world coordinate frame"?

content.raw: Yes, these are expected. They occur because the joint functions are set up differently between ODE and bullet. Model::LoadJoint calls joint->FillMsg, but the bullet hinge joints aren't actually created until the joints have been initialized. This may require some refactoring of the Joint and Model code.
content.html: Yes, these are expected. They occur because the joint functions are set up differently between ODE and bullet. Model::LoadJoint calls joint->FillMsg, but the bullet hinge joints aren't actually created until the joints have been initialized. This may require some refactoring of the Joint and Model code.

update.description:
The main feature of this pull request is a fix for bullet's revolute joint (BulletHingeJoint) so that it passes the same pendulum test as ODE (SimplePendulumTest). I did have to tweak the inertial parameters slightly in simple_pendulums_bullet.world, changing inertia values from 0 to 1e-6, so it does differ insubstantially from the ODE test.

I also made a few static functions in BulletTypes for converting between gazebo and bullet Vector3 and poses.

I filled in the BulletLink::OnPoseChange, so that Reset Model Poses, Reset World, and the move/rotate tools work.

I fixed a bug in the processing of physics messages, so the update rate, step size, and gravity can be adjusted from the gui.

I also added Link::GetWorldCoGPose, which is useful since the bullet functions define everything relative to the center of gravity of a rigid body.

I also added a SpawnDropCoG test, which spawns several spheres of different radii and different center of gravity locations. It's currently failing; I believe it is related to physics engine parameters, which will be addressed in a future pull request. I've added the failing tests to the description of issue #349.

update.description:
The main feature of this pull request is a fix for bullet's revolute joint (BulletHingeJoint) so that it passes the same pendulum test as ODE (SimplePendulumTest). I did have to tweak the inertial parameters slightly in simple_pendulums_bullet.world, changing inertia values from 0 to 1e-6, so it does differ insubstantially from the ODE test.

I also made a few static functions in BulletTypes for converting between gazebo and bullet Vector3 and poses.

I filled in the BulletLink::OnPoseChange, so that Reset Model Poses, Reset World, and the move/rotate tools work.

I fixed a bug in the processing of physics messages, so the update rate, step size, and gravity can be adjusted from the gui.

I also added Link::GetWorldCoGPose, which is useful since the bullet functions define everything relative to the center of gravity of a rigid body.

I also added a SpawnDropCoG test, which spawns several spheres of different radii and different center of gravity locations. It's currently failing; I believe it is related to physics engine parameters, which will be addressed in a future pull request. I've added the failing tests to the description of issue #349.
